awd_titl_txt: Conference: Women in Commutative Algebra II
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for participants of the "Women in Commutative Algebra II” (WICA II) workshop to be held at CIRM (Centro Internazionale per la Ricerca Matematica) in Trento, Italy, on October 16-20, 2023. Commutative algebra is an extremely vibrant field of mathematical research, with fundamental connections to many other disciplines, and has an influential female mathematician, Emmy Noether, as one of its founders. The workshop will feature research on seven different topics within commutative algebra, with fourteen group co-leaders suggesting problems of study and guiding the lines of inquiry. WICA II will expand the research portfolio and collaborative networks of the approximately forty-two participants in attendance. This workshop will create leadership opportunities and provide mentorship for early-career mathematicians, while also making a positive impact on those who are geographically isolated at their home institutions. 

The topics to be investigated at this conference include Lefschetz properties of graded algebras, tensor decompositions, Waldschmidt constants and resurgence, Rees algebras of determinantal ideals, probabilistic models in commutative algebra, commutative algebra aspects of Schubert Calculus, and free resolutions. These are themes of current interest in the field and the workshops will advance commutative algebra by making scientific advances on each of these topics.  More information can be found at the workshop website  https://mathstat.dal.ca/~faridi/WICAII.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The workshop Women in Commutative Algebra II was held at the international research center CIRM in Trento Italy on October 16-20, 2023. The main objectives of the Women in Commutative Algebra workshop series are to advance commutative algebra through cutting-edge research, to facilitate collaborative interaction between junior and senior mathematicians, and to provide mentoring for early career mathematicians.

 Intellectual Merit

Rather than featuring presentations, this workshop focused on research collaboration in small groups. It brought together seven research groups to address significant problems in commutative algebra, supported by collaborative efforts among experts in the field. Each group has two co-leaders, who are responsible for proposing one or several research problems, and 4-5 other participants. The groups focused on distinct but interconnected topics, advancing the understanding of algebraic invariants, structural properties of rings, and their applications in mathematics. The majority of the time in the conference was spent on research work within the small groups with some cross-group debriefing taking place at key points during the week.

The seven groups performed collaborative research on the following topics:

  • Free Resolutions. This group, led by Liana Sega and Oana Veliche, analyzed free resolutions over almost complete intersection rings, particularly those generated by general quadratic equations, describing key homological invariants such as Betti numbers. 
  • Blowup Algebras. Researchers led by Louiza Fouli and Kuei Nuan Lin established conditions for when certain blowup algebras possess the Gorenstein property, and calculated invariants like regularity and multiplicity.
  • Lefschetz Properties. This group, led Nasrin Altafi and Rosa Maria Miro Roig, explored families of Artinian Gorenstein algebras, uncovering new algebras with remarkable properties, in particular having the weak and strong Lefschetz properties.
  • Waldschmidt Constants and Point Configurations.  Focused on determining numerical invariants such as the Waldschmidt constant and resurgence, this group led by Elena Guardo and Susan Cooper studied geometric configurations of points in projective space. 
  • Geometric Vertex Decomposition and Frobenius Splitting. This group, led by Patricia Klein and Jenna Rajchgot, investigated the relationship between Frobenius splitting and geometric vertex decomposition, an operation that generalizes vertex decomposition of simplicial complexes to algebraic varieties. 
  • Tensor Decompositions. The group is led by Alessandra Bernardi and Maria Chiara Brambilla. The main objectives in their working program are to analyze the (non-)multiplicativity of tensor rank for special tensors investigating connections between geometric properties of tensors and their decompositions. 
  • Random monomial ideals. Led by Anna Maria Bigatti and Sonja Petrovic, the members started an exploration of probability models and how they can be used to generate and study families of monomial ideals. The goal is understanding how randomly generating samples can be used to uncover whether a property of an algebraic object is rare or expected. 

Broader Impacts

The  workshop fostered collaboration between researchers across continents.  It  had 47 participants from multiple countries: USA, Canada, Germany, Italy, Poland, Spain, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, Turkey, Bahrain, China, Mexico. Besides geographic diversity, participants comprised a variety of career levels and represented a variety of institutions  from R1 high research output universities to small liberal arts colleges. The research outcomes have implications for both pure and applied mathematics, enhancing understanding in computational algebra, singularity theory, and combinatorial geometry. Additionally, the collaborative environment promoted knowledge exchange and provided mentorship opportunities for early-career researchers.

 


Last Modified: 12/04/2024
Modified by: Alexandra Seceleanu
